title: What's the minimum number of 2s needed to write a positive integer?
body:
This is just for fun and inspired by Estimating pi, using only 2s.

For a positive integer 𝑛, let 𝑓𝑛 denote the minimum number of 2s needed to express 𝑛 using addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and exponentiation, together with the ability to concatenate 2s, so for example 2superscript2222222 is a valid expression. Other variants involving different sets of allowed operations are possible, of course. This function is very far from monotonic, so to smooth it out let's also consider

𝑔𝑛subscriptmax1𝑚𝑛𝑓𝑚

For example,

  • 𝑓12 (122)
  • 𝑓113 (11222)

Question: What can you say about 𝑓𝑛 and 𝑔𝑛? Can you give exact values for small values of 𝑛? Can you give (asymptotic or exact) upper bounds? Lower bounds?

As a simple example we can write any positive integer 𝑛 in the form superscript2𝑘superscript𝑛′ where superscript𝑛′superscript2𝑘 (superscript2𝑘 is just the leading digit in the binary expansion of 𝑛), which gives 𝑓𝑛𝑓𝑘1𝑓superscript𝑛′. If we write ℓ𝑛subscript2𝑛 then iterating this gives something like

This gives an upper bound growing something like ℓ𝑛superscriptℓ2𝑛superscriptℓ3𝑛… which I think is pessimistic. For example, in my answer to the linked question I show that

𝑓1488539268736

Let 𝑀 be a smooth manifold, and let 𝑝𝑀. A linear map :𝑣→superscript𝐶𝑀ℝ is called a derivation at 𝑝 if 𝑣𝑓𝑔𝑓𝑝𝑣𝑔𝑔𝑝𝑣𝑓 for all 𝑓𝑔superscript𝐶𝑀.

title: Definition of Equivalence Relation
body:
I was going through the text "Discrete Mathematics and its Application" by Kenneth Rosen (5th Edition) where I am across the definition of equivalence relation and felt that it is one sided.

Definition: A relation on a set A is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

Now let us analyze the situation of what equivalence is meant to us intuitively.

Let there be a binary relation 𝑅 defined on a set 𝐴. Now we suppose that 𝑅 be reflexive, symmetric and transitive.

So we have for 𝑎𝑏𝑐𝐴

  1. 𝑎𝑅𝑎 (by the reflexive property of R)

  2. if 𝑎𝑅𝑏 then 𝑏𝑅𝑎 (by the symmetric property of R)

  3. if 𝑎𝑅𝑏 and 𝑏𝑅𝑐 then 𝑎𝑅𝑐 (by the transitive property of R)

Intuitively we can satisfy ourselves with the fact that the above are the necessary conditions for 𝑅 to be equivalent. So "if 𝑅 is reflexive, symmetric and transitive, then 𝑅 is an equivalence relation"

Now working our intuition for equivalence relation similar-to we note the following.

Let similar-to be an equivalence relation on a set A, then for 𝑎𝑏𝑐𝐴 we have,

  1. similar-to𝑎𝑎 (by the intuitive knowledge of what similar-to means)

  2. if similar-to𝑎𝑏 then similar-to𝑏𝑎 (by the intuitive knowledge of what similar-to means)

  3. if similar-to𝑎𝑏 and similar-to𝑏𝑐 then similar-to𝑎𝑐 (by the intuitive knowledge of what similar-to means)

Now we see that (1) implies similar-to is reflexive, (2) implies that similar-to is symmetric and (3) implies that similar-to is transitive.

So we have "if similar-to is an equivalent relation then similar-to is reflexive, symmetric and transitive"

From the two intuitive implications we can conclude that A relation on a set A is called an equivalence relation if and only if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. and not what the book says. This definition makes quite sense unlike the book definition which says that if 𝑅 fails to be either reflexive or symmetric or transitive then 𝑅 may or may not be an equivalence relation, which after all gives a weird feeling.

Correct me if my logic is wrong.

For instance in order to calculate the optimal amount of ripple adders so as to minimise the execution time of the addition process:

ExecutionTime𝑛𝑘Δ4𝑘2𝑛𝑘4 𝑑ExecutionTime𝑛𝑘𝑑𝑘4Δ2𝑛Δsuperscript𝑘20 𝑘𝑛2

Clearly you can see that the execution time function is not continuous at all because 𝑘 is a natural number and so is 𝑛.
